I remember reading that dogs prefer human comfort when they're stressed and cats preferred solitude and were further stressed out by humans trying to comfort, which could make it hard to notice when they're sick or injured. I knew that was mostly bull because my cat bonded with me when she broke her tail. She came to me for comfort and security because she was in pain. She actually displayed signs of separation anxiety from then on as well. When we moved house both my cats were fine for weeks. They were in and out of the house and happily roaming then relaxing at home. I went away for a weekend and they both took off to our old place. They came up to me when I went there and called them, letting me pick them up and take them home with little trouble despite being scared and confused.

Be careful comparing RADAR bird surveys from the 1950s, 60s, and 70s with RADAR surveys from 1980s and beyond using FAA and Air Force RADARs. The newer RADARs  have what is called an Automated Clutter Eliminator (ACE) that tries to remove objects traveling slower than 80 miles per hour from the data/scope. This is designed to remove birds and other flying creatures, as well as ground traffic (yes, some of the older RADARs could generate major highway maps on their screens from just from vehicle traffic).

Climate change? Well, yes but don't say Man-made-climate change unless you've heard the speech from Christopher Monckton III Viscount of Brenchley. In all rain water, world-wide, there is Glyphosate. Glyphosate depletes the body of Zinc. The first symptoms of Zinc deficiency are tumors. Also, old growth forests had lots of Polypores. Polypores are what bees and birds use knowingly/unknowingly to kill mites that result in fatally ill health of offspring. Is it possible that the large increase in the raptor population has contributed to SOME of the decline in other bird populations? It's hugely disheartening to realize that was never the case.
